awd_titl_txt: CDS&E:   Collaborative:   A Higher Order PDE Toolkit for Computational Mathematics and Astrophysical Turbulence
awd_abstract_narration:
Our science and technology-driven society is immensely dependent on robust, reliable and highly accurate simulations of various natural phenomena. The scope of such natural phenomena is vast. In this proposal,  the PIs take the task of generating software that can robustly, reliably and with high accuracy simulate phenomena that have to do with the propagation of wave-like motions. Such computational codes are very useful in simulating problems in applied and computational mathematics as well as computational astrophysics.  The proposed effort seeks to develop a common software substrate for both those communities. The software is based on advanced computational algorithms and is intended to work very efficiently on modern generations of supercomputers that have been funded by the National Science Foundation. 

To solve the common problem faced by both communities the PIs develop a toolkit for higher order partial differential equation (PDE) methods. The proposed computational toolkit mainly includes two components. The first one is a multidimensional Riemann solver software that can work with some PDE systems. The second one is Discontinuous Galerkin (DG) schemes for some involution-constrained systems of hyperbolic PDEs such as Euler and magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) flows.

Project Outcomes Report for:-

CDS&E: Collaborative: A Higher Order PDE Toolkit for Computational Mathematics and Astrophysical Turbulence

      There is a great need in the field of astrophysical turbulence modelling to have numerical methods that minimize dissipation and dispersion. Such methods, especially when they are developed for magnetohydrodynamics (MHD), should also preserve the divergence-constraints in the underlying partial differential equations (a more recent outgrowth of the ideas of calculus). But what is the most natural way of achieving this goal? The answer is that that this goal is most easily achieved by using high order accurate methods drawn from computational mathematics. This establishes the commonality of goals that bring together the computational math community and the astrophysical turbulence  community under the aegis of this project.

      As part of this project, we had to develop higher order accurate methods. This was done by developing a class of numerical methods called Godunov methods. This class of methods is known to be unusually robust, even in the vicinity of strong shocks. Such strong shocks routinely occur in astrophysical simulations. It is for this reason that a common PDE toolkit was conceived.

      But the partial differential equations also have to respect internal symmetries, known as structures or constraints. For this reason, we developed constraint-preserving higher order Godunov schemes. This was a truly novel innovation that was not available to either of the target communities when this work was initially started.

      As part of this work, an educational website was also developed which includes educational movies and other resources, such as codes, for the target communities. In doing this research, as well as developing the website, we have raised the intellectual bar and also made free resources available to the general public.
